title: Newton woman facing assault, kidnapping, other charges around alleged unlicensed cosmetic surgery in Allston
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Dingrui Wang, 34, faces multiple charges for allegedly performing unlicensed cosmetic surgery causing permanent damage in Allston.
Wang allegedly administered a non-FDA-approved procedure, forcibly completing it despite victim's attempt to leave due to pain.
She also faces charges for misrepresenting medical credentials on a loan application, resulting in $37,379 in fraudulent loans.

title: Car rammed by train in Abington after breaking down on tracks
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: A 2007 Honda was hit by a MBTA train after breaking down on tracks in Abington, according to Transit Police.
The incident occurred around 8 p.m. near Plymouth St. The driver had exited the vehicle before the collision.
No casualties or injuries resulted from the collision, as the car was unoccupied during the impact, Transit Police reported.

title: Woman, 57, walking in road due to snow hit and killed by car on Route 28 in Wareham, DA says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: A 57-year-old woman was killed after being struck by a car on Route 28 in Wareham while walking due to snowy sidewalks.
A Volvo hit the woman and a male pedestrian; the driver remained at the scene and blamed traffic conditions.
The incident involved an earlier collision with a black truck, and an investigation by Plymouth DA's office is ongoing.

title: Former North Shore police officer gets prison time for child porn charge
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Former Gloucester police officer Alexander Aiello sentenced to four years for child pornography charges.
Aiello pleaded guilty after police found over 200 files of child abuse material on an encrypted thumb drive.
FBI investigation revealed Aiello used a Tor Browser for accessing child pornography; he will serve 5 years supervised release post-prison.

title: ‘The finest kind’: Gloucester mourns 7 lost in Lily Jean sinking as Coast Guard launches probe
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Seven people are presumed dead after the fishing boat Lily Jean sank off the coast of Cape Ann, Gloucester.
The U.S. Coast Guard will investigate the Lily Jean incident with the National Transportation Safety Board, taking several months.
State Senator Bruce Tarr praised the lost crew as 'the finest kind,' highlighting their dedication and legacy in Gloucester.

title: Why readers think Bill Belichick belonged in the Hall of Fame this year
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Bill Belichick was not selected as a first-ballot inductee for the Pro Football Hall of Fame's Class of 2026.
93% of over 450 Boston.com readers polled believe Belichick deserved Hall of Fame induction this year.
Some readers cited scandals and Belichick's record without Tom Brady as reasons for his lack of selection.

title: Which Patriots Super Bowl will you never forget?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: The New England Patriots prepare for their 12th Super Bowl appearance, evoking memories of past iconic victories.
Fans are invited to share their most memorable Patriots Super Bowl experiences for a Boston.com community feature.
Notable moments include Adam Vinatieri's 2002 kick, Malcolm Butler's interception, and Tom Brady's comeback vs. Falcons.

title: This runner is raising awareness about stroke and heart disease
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Liz Lang, 48, from Jackson, NJ, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon to raise awareness for stroke and heart disease.
Diagnosed with heart arrhythmia and antiphospholipid syndrome, Lang emphasizes self-advocacy and perseverance in health management.
Lang is fundraising for Tedy's Team, supporting research and outreach for stroke and heart disease awareness.

title: Once a patient, now a runner: She’s running for Boston Children’s Hospital
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Molly Kokoski, a 26-year-old Boston resident, will run the 130th Boston Marathon for Boston Children's Hospital.
Diagnosed with ulcerative colitis and dependent on an ostomy bag, Kokoski aims to raise money and inspire others.
She credits Boston Children's Hospital for saving her life and supporting her through childhood and early adulthood.

title: Saks OFF 5th to close Massachusetts stores
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Saks OFF 5th will close its Assembly Row (Somerville) and Wrentham stores as the parent company, Saks Global, files for bankruptcy.
Saks Global will focus on luxury retail, leaving only 12 Saks OFF 5th stores open to sell inventory from other brands.
The closures follow Saks Global's bankruptcy filing, attributed to competition and debt from acquiring Neiman Marcus.
